user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType:
```c
void UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    if (ReturnSize > 0)
    {
        /* Check for existing buffer and re-use if same size (should be!) */
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);
        if (StubPtr != NULL && StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize != ReturnSize)
        {
            UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
            StubPtr = NULL;
        }

        if (StubPtr == NULL)
        {
            StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);
            if (StubPtr == NULL)
            {
                UtAssert_Abort("Cannot set return buffer - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
            }
            else
            {
                StubPtr->FuncKey           = FuncKey;
                StubPtr->EntryType         = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER;
                StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr = malloc(ReturnSize);
                if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr == NULL)
                {
                    UtAssert_Abort("Cannot allocate data buffer - malloc() failed!");
                }
                else
                {
                    memset(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, 0, ReturnSize);
                    StubPtr->ModeFlags |= UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF;
                }

                StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize = ReturnSize;
            }
        }

        if (StubPtr != NULL)
        {
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position       = 0;
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr = TypeName;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType:
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
#define UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF 0x1U
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other code in the provided function and related definitions uses standard C language constructs and standard library calls (size_t, NULL, malloc, memset, pointer dereferences, control-flow statements, macro integer suffixes like 0x1U, typedefs of user-defined identifiers, etc.). There are no occurrences of known compiler/language extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_..., typeof, anonymous structs/unions, designated initializers, or other vendor-specific keywords in the shown code, so those fragments do not need investigation for Rule 1.2.
